text: Family Member: And I had to go in. Dr. F___ was over at the C___’s Hospital. I went in with Dr. S____. Doctor: You did not tell me she had a mini-stroke. Family Member: They put a PFO closure and found a hole in my heart. Doctor: Why didn’t you tell me? Oh, gosh. Family Member: Yeah. I have a closure piece in there. Doctor: You okay now? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: She looks great. Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Actually, you both, you both have come a long way. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: From our first days of meeting. Family Member: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?

text: Patient: So, the two medicines that you’ve got potential… Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: What are the side effects? Doctor: Well, tiredness. Hi? Patient: Well, that was what? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Doctor: That was Xtandi. So, tiredness. One of them has a low platelet issue. Like, you take it, and your platelets are gone. You stop it; the platelets come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that, Patient: No.

text: Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And your cancer, really, is not showing any major activity, so. Family Member: Great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Uh, uh, the PSA looks normal. text: Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different. Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard.

text: Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down.

text: Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial –

Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial –

text: Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m not gonna fuss. I’m gonna fast forward to say well, whatever that shows I think the question is, you know, what are my options. So, here’s where I’m at. If it’s more than bone, meaning, oh, shoot, maybe that thingy in the liver and the lymph nodes and all that is actually there again and that other one was sort of a fake out then I think you need chemo and I think we’ve been stalling enough for a while that the inevitable is about to happen Mr. H____ you just, you’re gonna, we’re just gonna have to do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: and that’s with docetaxel and Taxotere is the name of the chemo and we do have studies with that so I just, you know, I always want to make sure we talk about that. So, you’d get on Taxotere just alone once every three weeks. It’s an hour infusion. Standard of care anywhere you go in the US. Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then our studies are Taxotere plus high-dose vitamin C versus just the Taxotere. So, two-thirds of the people will get vitamin C. The other one third will just get the chemo. So, everybody gets chemo no matter how I swing this

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
